page.title: 19CRAIG PHADRIG FOREST
page.content: BENEATH AND AROUND THE REMAINS OF A VITRIFIED FORT, CRAIG PHADRIG HILL IS FORESTED AND MAINTAINED BY THE FORESTRY COMMISSION. THE FOREST COVERS AN AREA OF 85 HECTARES.THERE ARE APPROXIMATELY 130,000 TREES THERE. THE FIRST FORESTRY COMMISSION TREE WAS PLANTED IN 1926. THE TYPES OF TREES FOUND IN THE FOREST ARE SCOTS PINE, DOUGLAS FIR, SITKA SPRUCE, LODGE POLE PINE, THUYA AND TSUGA. TREES FELLED IN 1985 ARE TO BE USED FOR SAWN TIMBER, BUILDING AND PULP FOR PAPER. THE FOREST WILL BE RESTOCKED. THE WILDLIFE TO BE FOUND THERE INCLUDES ROE DEER, STOATS, WEASELS AND VARIOUS BIRDS.FOREST PATROLS ARE NECESSARY TO PREVENT POACHING, STEALING OF CUT TIMBER AND TO CONTROL ANY FIRES. THERE ARE NO OFFICIAL FOREST WALKS. UPKEEP OF THE FOREST COSTS Â£7000 PER YEAR.
